docs.title: S1 — Lack of common definitions
docs.text: Problem Needs Recommendations There is a generalised lack of common explicit definitions about the terms used by user communities. Need for harmonisation across disciplines. Communities should generate clear, precise definitions for concepts, metadata, and data schemas. Definitions must be public, PID‑referenced, and shared in EOSC.

docs.title: S2 — Lack of shared semantic artefacts
docs.text: Problem Needs Recommendations Common semantic artefacts (ontologies, schemas) are often missing across communities. Need for principled approaches and tools for ontology and metadata schema creation, maintenance, governance, and use. Semantic artefacts should be openly licensed and accessible.

docs.title: S3 — Lack of reference repositories for semantic artefacts
docs.text: Problem Needs Recommendations There is a generalised lack of common reference repositories or registries of semantic artefacts. Need to harmonise data of the same type. Every semantic artefact in EOSC must include sufficient documentation, examples, and conceptual diagrams.

docs.title: S4 — Poor documentation and fragmented metadata schemas
docs.text: Problem Needs Recommendations Data collections are poorly documented; no common metadata schema across communities. EOSC should support a repository of semantic artefacts and a governance framework. Propose a minimum metadata model (DCAT‑AP, DDI 4 Core, DataCite, OpenAIRE). Extend to software, workflows, protocols, hardware. Provide federation/harvesting building blocks.

docs.title: S5 — Lack of semantic expertise in communities
docs.text: Problem Needs Recommendations Some communities lack semantic expertise and skills. Capacity building and training. Develop training, guidance, and community support structures to improve semantic literacy.

docs.title: T1 — Fragmented authentication and authorisation
docs.text: Problem Needs Recommendations Authentication and authorisation must often be repeated for each community or service. Seamless authentication and rights acquisition for EOSC services. Use open specifications to ensure technical interoperability when establishing EOSC services.

docs.title: T2 — Heterogeneous data formats
docs.text: Problem Needs Recommendations Research data exists in many formats (CSV, JSON, XML, NetCDF, FITS, etc.). A trusted, sustainable cross‑community framework; a minimum metadata application profile for EOSC. Define a common security and privacy framework and establish trustworthy data‑exchange processes.

docs.title: T3 — Difficulty finding data at different granularities
docs.text: Problem Needs Recommendations Coarse‑grained or fine‑grained data from other communities may be difficult to find. Discovery mechanisms supporting multiple levels of granularity. Provide clear, understandable SLAs for all EOSC resource providers.

docs.title: T4 — PID fragmentation and inconsistency
docs.text: Problem Needs Recommendations Multiple PID providers with different policies; some PIDs not resolvable; duplicates exist. A common, well‑understood PID policy across communities. EOSC must enable easy access to heterogeneous data formats and provide tools to overcome differences. Provide coarse‑ and fine‑grained search tools. Establish a clear EOSC PID policy accommodating diverse practices.

docs.text: Within the scope of the FAIR-EASE (FE) project, a custom-made DCAT-FE model was introduced. DCAT-FE can be applied independently of whether data is published via traditional catalogues or through subsetting services. The DCAT-FE specification is openly available on the FE GitHub (https://github.com/fair-ease/asset-standards/tree/main/DCAT-AP) and will be actively maintained post-project via version-controlled updates to support the inclusion of emerging (meta)data fields. Through its adoption, DCAT-FE has the potential to evolve into a cross-disciplinary community standard for dataset description across the EOSC ecosystem. To showcase the added benefits of adopting DCAT-FE, in the context of FAIR-EASE, the Interdisciplinary Data Discovery and Access Service (IDDAS) was developed. The IDDAS contains a User Interface, DCAT-AP profile, SPARQL API and VRE widget that allows users to search for relevant data using a faceted search based on keywords connected to the metadata. By testing and setting up this type of searching and accessing of multi-disciplinary data in FAIR-EASE, the improvements over traditional access catalogues are identified. As such, not the IDDAS as an infrastructure will remain operational, but rather the developments that showed improvements in terms of multi-disciplinary data access will be brought forward, demonstrated and possibly exploited in light of the EOSC federation of nodes. This includes candidate nodes such as Blue-Cloud2026 and ENVRI RI’s, (thematic) and French Data-Terra (national) that have direct relevance to these improvements like the RDF multi-disciplinary metadata description and semantic harmonization. For more information see: https://zenodo.org/records/15836888
